Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Roust \Roust\, n. [Cf. Icel. r["o]st an estuary.] A strong tide or current, especially in a narrow channel. [Written also {rost}, and {roost}.] --Jamieson. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44
The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition: Roost \Roost\, v. t. See {Roust}, v. t. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Roost \Roost\, n. [AS. hr[=o]st; akin to OD. roest roost, roesten to roost, and probably to E. roof. Cf. {Roof}.] 1. The pole or other support on which fowls rest at night; a perch. [1913 Webster]
He clapped his wings upon his roost. --Dryden. [1913 Webster]
2. A collection of fowls roosting together. [1913 Webster]
{At roost}, on a perch or roost; hence, retired to rest. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Roost \Roost\, v. i. [imp. & p. p. {Roosted}; p. pr. & vb. n. {Roosting}.] 1. To sit, rest, or sleep, as fowls on a pole, limb of a tree, etc.; to perch. --Wordsworth. [1913 Webster]
2. Fig.; To lodge; to rest; to sleep. [1913 Webster]
O, let me where thy roof my soul hath hid, O, let me roost and nestle there. --Herbert. [1913 Webster]

roost n 1: a shelter with perches for fowl or other birds 2: a perch on which domestic fowl rest or sleep v 1: sit, as on a branch; "The birds perched high in the treee" [syn: {perch}, {rest}] 2: settle down or stay, as if on a roost
